{{redirect|Glossy|the fashion website|Digiday}} [[File:Gloss light Illuminates.jpg|Gloss light Illuminates|thumb|Gloss reflection]] '''Gloss''' is an [[optical]] property which indicates how well a surface reflects light in a [[specular]] (mirror-like) direction. It is one of important parameters that are used to describe the [[visual appearance]] of an object. The factors that affect gloss are the refractive index of the material, the angle of incident light and the surface [[topography]].
Apparent gloss depends on the amount of ''specular'' reflection – light reflected from the surface in an equal amount and the symmetrical angle to the one of incoming light – in comparison with [[diffuse reflection|''diffuse'' reflection]] – the amount of light scattered into other directions.
==Theory== [[File:Lambert2.gif|thumb|right|Specular and diffuse reflection]] When light illuminates an object, it interacts with it in a number of ways:
* Absorbed within it (largely responsible for colour) * Transmitted through it (dependent on the surface transparency and opacity) * Scattered from or within it (diffuse reflection, haze and transmission) * Specularly reflected from it (gloss)
Variations in surface texture directly influence the level of specular reflection. Objects with a smooth surface, i.e. highly polished or containing coatings with finely dispersed pigments, appear shiny to the eye due to a large amount of light being reflected in a specular direction whilst rough surfaces reflect no specular light as the light is scattered in other directions and therefore appears dull. The image forming qualities of these surfaces are much lower making any reflections appear blurred and distorted.
Substrate material type also influences the gloss of a surface. Non-metallic materials, i.e. plastics etc. produce a higher level of reflected light when illuminated at a greater illumination angle due to light being absorbed into the material or being diffusely scattered depending on the colour of the material. Metals do not suffer from this effect producing higher amounts of reflection at any angle.
The Fresnel formula gives the specular reflectance, <math> R_s </math>, for an unpolarized light of [[intensity (physics)|intensity]] <math> I_0 </math>, at angle of incidence <math> i </math>, giving the intensity of specularly reflected beam of intensity <math> I_r </math>, while the refractive index of the surface specimen is <math> m </math>.
The [[Fresnel equation]] is given as follows : <math> R_s = \frac{I_r}{I_0} </math>
:<math> R_s = \frac{1}{2} \left[\left(\frac{\cos i - \sqrt{m^2 - \sin^2 i}}{\cos i + \sqrt{m^2 - \sin^2 i}}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{m^2 \cos i - \sqrt{m^2 - \sin^2 i}}{m^2 \cos i + \sqrt{m^2 - \sin^2 i}}\right)^2\right]</math>
===Surface roughness===
[[Image:Nanorough.gif|right|thumb|300px|Figure1:Specular reflection of light from a rough surface]]
Surface roughness in micrometer range influences the specular reflectance levels. The diagram on the right depicts the reflection at an angle <math> i </math> on a rough surface with a characteristic roughness height <math> h </math>. The path difference between rays reflected from the top and bottom of the surface bumps is:
:<math>\Delta r = 2h \cos i \;</math>
When the wavelength of the light is <math>\lambda</math>, the phase difference will be: :<math>\Delta \phi = \frac{4\pi h \cos i}{\lambda} \;</math>
If <math>\Delta \phi \;</math> is small, the two beams (see Figure 1) are nearly in phase and therefore the specimen surface can be considered smooth. But when <math>\Delta \phi = \pi \;</math>, then beams are not in phase and through interference, cancellation of each other will occur. Low intensity of specularly reflected light means the surface is rough and it scatters the light in other directions. If an arbitrary criterion for smooth surface is <math>\Delta \phi < \frac{\pi}{2} </math>, then substitution into the equation above will produce:
:<math> h < \frac {\lambda}{8 \cos i} \;</math>
This smooth surface condition is known as the Rayleigh criterion.
===History===
The earliest studies of gloss perception are attributed to Ingersoll<ref>Ingersoll Elec. World 63,645 (1914), Elec. World 64, 35 (1915); Paper 27, 18 (Feb. 9, 1921), and U. S. Patent 1225250 (May 8, 1917)</ref><ref>Ingersoll R. S., The Glarimeter, “An instrument for measuring the gloss of paper”. J.Opt. Soc. Am. 5.213 (1921)</ref> who in 1914 examined the effect of gloss on paper. By quantitatively measuring gloss using instrumentation Ingersoll based his research around the theory that light is polarised in specular reflection whereas diffusely reflected light is non-polarized. The Ingersoll “glarimeter” had a specular geometry with incident and viewing angles at 57.5°. Using this configuration gloss was measured using a contrast method which subtracted the specular component from the total reflectance using a polarizing filter.
In the 1930s work by A. H. Pfund,<ref>A. H. Pfund, ”The measurement of gloss“, J. Opt. Soc. Am. 20, 23.23 (1930)</ref> suggested that although specular shininess is the basic (objective) evidence of gloss, actual surface glossy appearance (subjective) relates to the contrast between specular shininess and the diffuse light of the surrounding surface area (now called “contrast gloss” or “luster”).
If black and white surfaces of the same shininess are visually compared, the black surface will always appear glossier because of the greater contrast between the specular highlight and the black surroundings as compared to that with white surface and surroundings. Pfund was also the first to suggest that more than one method was needed to analyze gloss correctly.
In 1937 Hunter,<ref>Hunter, R. S., “Methods of determining gloss”, RP958 J. Res. NBS, Volume 18 (1937)</ref> as part of his research paper on gloss, described six different visual criteria attributed to apparent gloss. The following diagrams show the relationships between an incident beam of light, I, a specularly reflected beam, S, a diffusely reflected beam, D and a near-specularly reflected beam, B.
* Specular gloss – the perceived brightness and the brilliance of highlights
[[File:Specular gloss.jpg|Specular gloss]]
Defined as the ratio of the light reflected from a surface at an equal but opposite angle to that incident on the surface.
* Sheen – the perceived shininess at low grazing angles
[[File:Sheen.jpg|Sheen]]
Defined as the gloss at grazing angles of incidence and viewing
* Contrast gloss – the perceived brightness of specularly and diffusely reflecting areas
[[File:Contrast gloss.jpg|Contrast gloss]]
Defined as the ratio of the specularly reflected light to that diffusely reflected normal to the surface;
* Absence of bloom – the perceived cloudiness in reflections near the specular direction
[[File:Absence of bloom.jpg|Absence of bloom]]
Defined as a measure of the absence of haze or a milky appearance adjacent to the specularly reflected light: haze is the inverse of absence-of-bloom
* Distinctness of image gloss – identified by the distinctness of images reflected in surfaces
[[File:Distinctness of image gloss.jpg|Distinctness of image gloss]]
Defined as the sharpness of the specularly reflected light
* Surface texture gloss – identified by the lack of surface texture and surface blemishes
Defined as the uniformity of the surface in terms of visible texture and defects (orange peel, scratches, inclusions etc.)
A surface can therefore appear very shiny if it has a well-defined specular reflectance at the specular angle. The perception of an image reflected in the surface can be degraded by appearing unsharp, or by appearing to be of low contrast. The former is characterised by the measurement of the distinctness-of-image and the latter by the haze or contrast gloss.
[[File:Gloss-samples.gif|Gloss-samples]]
In his paper Hunter also noted the importance of three main factors in the measurement of gloss: * The amount of light reflected in the specular direction * The amount and way in which the light is spread around the specular direction * The change in specular reflection as the specular angle changes
For his research he used a [[glossmeter]] with a specular angle of 45° as did most of the first photoelectric methods of that type, later studies however by Hunter and Judd in 1939,<ref>Judd, D B (1937), Gloss and glossiness. Am. Dyest. Rep. 26, 234–235 </ref> on a larger number of painted samples, concluded that the 60 degree geometry was the best angle to use so as to provide the closest correlation to a visual observation.
===Standard gloss measurement===
Standardisation in gloss measurement was led by Hunter and ASTM (American Society for Testing and Materials) who produced ASTM D523 Standard test method for specular gloss in 1939. This incorporated a method for measuring gloss at a specular angle of 60°. Later editions of the Standard (1951) included methods for measuring at 20° for evaluating high gloss finishes, developed at the DuPont Company (Horning and Morse, 1947) and 85° (matte, or low, gloss).
ASTM has a number of other gloss-related standards designed for application in specific industries including the old 45° method which is used primarily now used for glazed ceramics, polyethylene and other plastic films.
In 1937, the paper industry adopted a 75° specular-gloss method because the angle gave the best separation of coated book papers.<ref>Institute of Paper Chemistry (1937); Hunter (1958)</ref> This method was adopted in 1951 by the Technical Association of Pulp and Paper Industries as TAPPI Method T480.
In the paint industry, measurements of the specular gloss are made according to International Standard ISO 2813 (BS 3900, Part 5, UK; DIN 67530, Germany; NFT 30-064, France; AS 1580, Australia; JIS Z8741, Japan, are also equivalent). This standard is essentially the same as ASTM D523 although differently drafted.
Studies of polished metal surfaces and anodised aluminium automotive trim in the 1960s by Tingle,<ref>Tingle, W. H., and Potter, F. R., “New Instrument Grades for Polished Metal Surfaces,” Product Engineering, Vol 27, March 1961.</ref><ref>Tingle, W. H., and George, D. J., “Measuring Appearance Characteristics of Anodized Aluminum Automotive Trim,” Report No. 650513, Society of Automotive Engineers, May 1965.</ref> Potter and George led to the standardisation of gloss measurement of high gloss surfaces by goniophotometry under the designation ASTM E430. In this standard it also defined methods for the measurement of distinctness of image gloss and reflection haze.

[[File:GozoVictoriaCittadella.jpg|thumb|Natural Science Museum on the right]] The '''Gozo Nature Museum''',{{cite web|title=Gozo Nature Museum|url=http://heritagemalta.org/museums-sites/gozo-nature-museum/|website=Heritage Malta|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110104127/http://heritagemalta.org/museums-sites/gozo-nature-museum/|archivedate=10 January 2018}} formerly known as the '''Natural Science Museum''', is a museum in [[Victoria, Gozo|Victoria]], on the island of [[Gozo]], [[Malta]]. It has been open to public since 1991. It is housed in a group of houses within the [[Cittadella (Gozo)|Cittadella]], the oldest part of the city. These houses date back to various ages: the older one, which was an inn, to 1495; the other to the 17th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.gozo.gov.mt/pages.aspx?page=61 |title=Archaeology Museum |publisher=Malta Information Technology Agency |accessdate=12 March 2010}}{{cite web |work=[[Heritage Malta]] official website |title=Heritage Malta Museums |url=http://www.heritagemalta.org/museums/naturalscience/naturalscienceinfo.html |accessdate=12 March 2010}} The Natural Science Museum shows collections "relating to the Island’s geology, minerals, marine life, insects, local habitats and ecosystems" as well as national plants (including the [[Maltese Rock Centaury]]), human and animal evolution. During later years, this building was used as an inn for visitors, and is mentioned in Thomas McGill’s “Handbook, or Guide, for Strangers visiting Malta” of 1839,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJ8NAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Guide+for+Strangers+visiting+Malta&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false| title=A hand book, or guide for strangers who visiting Malta|publisher=Tonna |page=144| accessdate=12 March 2010}} and described as
an excellent house of entertainment offering clean and comfortable beds and reasonably-priced dinners.
During World War II the building served as a shelter for families who sought refuge during aerial bombings. The buildings which house the museum are listed on the [[National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]].{{cite web|title=Natural Science Museum|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/01240.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=17 October 2015|date=28 December 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of museums in Malta]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gozo.gov.mt/GozoPortal/tourism/museums/natural_science_museum.aspx Official website] * [http://www.visitmalta.com/natural-science-museum museum on Official Malta Tourism website] {{coord|36.0467|14.239|display=title}} {{Citta Victoria}} [[Category:Natural history museums]] [[Category:Museums in Malta]] [[Category:Victoria, Gozo]] [[Category:National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]] [[Category:Sites managed by Heritage Malta]]

The '''Körber European Science Prize''' is presented annually by the [[Körber Foundation]] in [[Hamburg]] honoring outstanding scientists working in [[Europe]] for their promising research projects. The 750,000 euro prize promotes research projects in the [[life sciences]] and [[physical sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Körber European Science Prize |url=https://www.nat.fau.eu/research/prizes/research-prizes/koerber-prize/|publisher=[[Friedrich Alexander University of Erlangen-Nürnberg]]|accessdate=23 September 2017}}</ref>
== History== The prize was initiated by the entrepreneur [[Kurt A. Körber]] with the help of Reimar Lüst, the president of the [[Max Planck Society]]. The first award was in 1985. At first, European research teams were honored, but since 2005, only individuals qualify.<ref>Körber Foundation: „Excellent Brains. 25 Years of Cutting-Edge Science” 2009, p. 4 et seq.</ref>
== Selection process== Candidates for the prize need not be from Europe, but they must be living in Europe.<ref name="guidelines">{{citation|title=Guidelines for the awarding of the Körber European Science Prize|url=http://www.koerber-stiftung.de/fileadmin/user_upload/wissenschaft/koerber-preis/pdf/Guidelines%20of%20the%20Koerber%20European%20Science%20Prize%202011.pdf|format=pdf|date=June 2011|publisher=Körber-Stiftung|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> Renowned scientists from all over Europe, grouped into two Search Committees, select promising candidates. The awards are annual and alternate between the life and physical sciences. Those who are shortlisted are then asked to submit a detailed proposal for a research project which is then judged in two rounds of assessment by the Search Committee. The work of the Search Committee is supported by international experts. A maximum of five candidates are subsequently recommended to the Trustee Committee which, based on a summary of expert assessments, previous publications and scientific career history, decides on the new prizewinner. A personal application is not allowed.
== Prize money== All prizewinners receive a certificate and 750,000 euro prize money. The prizewinners can keep 10 percent of the money for themselves and must spend the rest on research in Europe in three to five years. Aside from these restrictions they alone can decide how to use the money.<ref name="guidelines"/>
== Presentation== The prize is presented every year in the Great Hall of [[Hamburg Rathaus|Hamburg City Hall]] in the presence of the Mayor of the Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg and 600 guests from science, industry, politics, and society.
== Winners== *1985: Applications of Shock Waves in Medicine, Walter Brendel, Michael Delius, Georg Enders, Joseph Holl, Gustav Paumgartner, Tilman Sauerbruch *1985: Back Pressure Casting Technology, Teodor Balevski, Rumen Batschvarov, Emil Momtschilov, Dragan Nenov, Rangel Zvetkov *1986: Retrovirus Research ([[AIDS]]), Jean-Claude Gluckman, Sven Haahr, George Janossy, David Klatzmann, [[Luc Montagnier]], Paul Rácz *1987: Further Development of [[Electron Holography]], Karl-Heinz Herrmann, Friedrich Lenz, Hannes Lichte, [[Gottfried Möllenstedt]] *1987: Creating Ultralow Temperatures, [[Riitta Hari]], Matti Krusius, [[Olli V. Lounasmaa]], Martti Salomaa *1988: Extending the Hamburg [[Pyrolytic Technique]] to Destroy Toxic Wastes, Alfons Buekens, Vasilij Dragalov, [[Walter Kaminsky]], [[Hansjörg Sinn]] *1989: Active Substances from Plant Cell Cultures, Christian Brunold, Yury Y. {{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=April 2012}} {{Expert needed|Biography|date=November 2008}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Laurance Doyle | image = | image_size = 180px | caption = Dr Laurance Doyle | residence = [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View]], [[California|CA]], United States | occupation = [[Astrophysicist]]
[[SETI Institute]]
[[NASA Ames Research Center]] | education = [[Master of Science|M.S.]] [[San Diego State University]] (1982)
[[Ph.D.]] [[University of Heidelberg]] (1986) }} '''Laurance R. Doyle''' (born 1953) is an American scientist who received his Ph.D. from the [[Ruprecht Karl University of Heidelberg]]. He has worked at the [[SETI Institute]] since 1987 where he is a principal investigator and astrophysicist. His main area of study has been the formation and detection of [[extrasolar planets]],[http://www.springerlink.com/(yggavx45p0uthu55gflyqz55)/app/home/contribution.asp?referrer=parent&backto=issue,11,12;journal,10,210;linkingpublicationresults,1:400258,1] but he has also worked on communications theory. In particular he has written on how patterns in animal communication relate to humans with an emphasis on [[cetaceans]]. He grew up on a [[dairy farm]] in [[Cambria, California]] and therefore, didn't have much access to information about [[star]]s. But by reading books at the local library, Doyle was able to develop his knowledge in [[astronomy]], and eventually obtain his [[Bachelor's degree|Bachelor]]'s and [[Master's degree|Master]]'s of Science degrees in astronomy from [[San Diego State University]]. His first job was at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] as an imaging engineer, where he was in charge of analyzing pictures of [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]] sent from the spacecraft [[Voyager program|Voyager]]. He moved to [[Heidelberg]], Germany, to help analyze images of [[Halley's Comet]]. He got his doctorate in [[Astrophysics]] at the [[University of Heidelberg]]. In May 2005, he appeared on a [[National Geographic Channel]] special titled ''Extraterrestrial.'' He also appeared in the episode "Will We Survive First Contact," of [[The Science Channel]] series titled ''Morgan Freeman's Through the Wormhole''. Doyle is currently seeking to compare [[dolphin]] whistles and baby [[Babbling|babble]] in an attempt to make predictions about [[Extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial]] communications. He believes that by measuring the complexity of communications for different species on Earth, we could get a good indication of how advanced an extraterrestrial signal is. His study determined that babies babble over 800 different sounds with the same amount of frequency as dolphins. As they grow older, those sounds decrease to around 50 and become more repetitious. The study found that baby dolphins develop similarly in regards to their whistling. Doyle is faculty at Principia College and the founding Director of [http://www.principiacollege.edu/imop Principia College's Institute for the Metaphysics of Physics], founded in 2014. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060903080122/http://faculty.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/faculty/bjmccowan/Pubs/McCowanetal.JCP.2002.pdf NASA workshop] *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060903080122/http://faculty.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/faculty/bjmccowan/Pubs/McCowanetal.JCP.2002.pdf |date=September 3, 2006 |title=Paper he co-authored on communications }} *[http://www.space.com/searchforlife/seti_doyle_whale_060126.html Essay by him on Space.com about whales] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060704193126/http://www.seti.org/site/pp.asp?c=ktJ2J9MMIsE&b=277932 SETI Profile] *[http://scicom.ucsc.edu/SciNotes/0601/seti/index.html Profile of the Drake equation led by Doyle] *[https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.02/alien.html Wired article] {{DEFAULTSORT:Doyle, Laurance}} [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:American Christian Scientists]] [[Category:Search for extraterrestrial intelligence]] [[Category:Heidelberg University alumni]] [[Category:San Diego State University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1953 births]]

This is a list of notable [[tornado]]es, [[tornado outbreak]]s, and [[tornado outbreak sequence]]s that have occurred in [[Canada]] in the 21st century. (2001 through 2100). Due to increasing detection, particularly in the US and southern Canada, numbers of counted tornadoes have increased markedly in recent decades although number of actual tornadoes and counted significant tornadoes has not. In older events, the number of tornadoes officially counted is likely underestimated.
On average, there are around 80 confirmed and unconfirmed tornadoes that touch down in Canada each year, with most occurring in [[Southern Ontario]], the southern [[Canadian Prairies]] and southern [[Quebec]]. Canada ranks as the second country in the world with the most tornadoes per year, after the US. The most common types are F0 to F2 in damage intensity level and usually result in minor structural damage to barns, wood fences, [[roof shingle]]s, chimneys, uprooted or snapped tree limbs and downed power lines. Fewer than 5% of tornadoes in Canada are rated F3 or higher in intensity, where wind speeds are in excess of {{convert|225|km/h|abbr=on}}. Prior to April 1, 2013, Canada used a slightly modified [[Fujita scale]], and as of that date the [[Enhanced Fujita scale]], again slightly modified, was put into use to rate tornado intensity, based on the damage to buildings and vegetation.<ref name="ehfs">{{Cite web |url=https://ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=41E875DA-1 |title=Enhanced Fujita Scale (EF-Scale) |access-date=2017-02-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407223004/http://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=41E875DA-1 |archive-date=2017-04-07 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
[[Ontario]], [[Alberta]], [[Manitoba]] and [[Saskatchewan]] all average 15 tornadoes per season, followed by Quebec with fewer than 10. [[New Brunswick]] and the [[British Columbia Interior]] are also recognized tornado zones. All other [[Provinces and territories of Canada|provinces and territories]] have significantly less threat from tornadoes. The peak season in Canada is in the summer months when clashing air masses move north, as opposed to the spring season in the United States southern-central plains, although tornadoes in Canada have occurred in spring, fall and very rarely winter.
The reported increase in numbers of tornadoes in recent years may reflect more reporting by citizens and media involvement rather than an actual increase in tornado occurrence (although some natural increase has not been ruled out), in addition to better detection technology i.e. [[Pulse-Doppler radar|Doppler]] [[weather radar]] and [[satellite imagery]]. The upswing could also be attributed to other factors, such as improved aerial and ground damage assessment after the fact in sparsely populated areas (particularly the case in remote parts of the Canadian Prairies and [[Northern Ontario]], for example), better trained spotter capabilities and increased use of digital recording devices by citizens. Tornadoes in Canada are enough of a threat for a [[Emergency population warning|public warning system]] to be in place, overseen by the national weather agency, [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Environment Canada]] (EC).
For a variety of reasons, such as Canada's lower population density and generally stronger housing construction due to the colder climate, Canadian tornadoes have historically caused far fewer fatalities than tornadoes in the United States. The deadliest tornado in Canadian history, the [[Regina Cyclone]] of June 30, 1912, does not even rank in the top 25 when compared to American tornado fatalities. Urban centres are not immune from the threat of severe tornadoes. Nine medium to large size Canadian cities have been hit by significant strength tornadoes (F3 or higher), which caused large-scale damage and fatalities: [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]] (1912); [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]] (1946 and 1974); [[Sarnia]] (1953); [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]] (1970); [[Woodstock, Ontario|Woodstock]] (1979); [[London, Ontario|London]] (1984); [[Barrie]] (1985); [[Edmonton]] (1987); [[Goderich, Ontario|Goderich]] (2011); and [[National Capital Region (Canada)|Ottawa-Gatineau]] (2018).
All figures for damages are in [[Canadian dollar]]s.

===2005=== * May 23 – a tornado touches down in and around [[Nipawin, Saskatchewan]]. *June 4 – several cold-core funnel clouds were spotted in [[Central Alberta|Central]] and [[Southern Alberta]]. Four of which briefly touched the ground. Several trees were damaged. * June 21 – A severe thunderstorm spawned one tornado near [[Lethbridge, Alberta]]. Several funnel clouds and golf ball size hail was reported from Lethbridge to [[Taber, Alberta|Taber]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20121012232946/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=e2fd1146-d04b-4a69-a3f1-4929033ebc19&sponsor= Wild weather spawns tornadoes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * July 2 – a tornado touched down about {{convert|25|km|abbr=on}} west of [[Estevan, Saskatchewan]]. * August 19 – [[Southern Ontario tornado outbreak of 2005]]. These associated storms caused extensive widespread damage in a path from [[Stratford, Ontario|Stratford]] ({{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} west of [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]]), to [[Peterborough, Ontario|Peterborough]], and along [[Georgian Bay]] near [[Collingwood, Ontario|Collingwood]]. A storm cell just to the north of [[Fergus, Ontario|Fergus]] spawned two F2 strength tornadoes that were particularly damaging, tearing apart trees, farms and overturning automobiles driving on a highway. The first tornado tracked through [[Perth East, Ontario|Milverton]] to [[Conestogo Lake]] (west of [[Elmira, Ontario|Elmira]]). The second moved from [[Salem, Wellington County|Salem]] to Lake Bellwood (north of [[Guelph]]). The same storm cell later triggered a [[tornado warning]] in [[Toronto]] and caused extensive flooding with over {{convert|140|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in some northern sections of the city, washing out many roads as well as damaging infrastructure such as storm sewers and electrical systems. An unusual tornado possibly touched down within the Toronto city limits, although never officially confirmed by Environment Canada. In its wake, the storm left a trail of damage that, according to the Insurance Bureau of Canada, represented the highest insured loss in the province's history, exceeding $500 million. That's more than two and a half times Ontario's losses during the infamous [[January 1998 North American ice storm|ice storm of 1998]] and the second largest loss event in Canadian history. * November 9 – [[Hamilton, Ontario]], a late-season tornado tears off part of the roof of a school and damages businesses and homes in the area. See [[Hamilton, Ontario tornado of 2005]].
===2006=== * July 4 – an F1 strikes [[Glassville, New Brunswick]], {{convert|40|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Perth Andover, New Brunswick|Perth Andover]]. The same storm system spawned an outbreak of fourteen confirmed tornadoes<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ontario.hazards.ca/historical/Tornado_Ontario-e.html |title=Environment Canada – Historical Tornado-Related Events |access-date=2007-10-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407001419/http://ontario.hazards.ca/historical/Tornado_Ontario-e.html |archive-date=2010-04-07 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> mostly concentrated north of [[Peterborough, Ontario|Peterborough]] in the [[Dysart et al, Ontario|Haliburton]], [[Kawartha Lakes|Kawartha]] and [[South Algonquin|Madawaska]] areas, which damaged cottages in the area, some severely. It was the most tornadoes confirmed in Ontario in a single 24-hour span day since 1985 and matched the annual provincial average. The strongest were two F2s, one that struck an isolated area near [[Bancroft, Ontario|Bancroft]] and the other that made a direct hit on the town of Combermere. * August 5 – in Gull Lake, Manitoba an F2 tornado killed a woman at a campground north of [[Winnipeg]]. * August 15 -an F1 tornado impacted the area of [[Pokemouche, New Brunswick|Pokemouche]] and [[Evangeline, Gloucester County, New Brunswick|Evangeline, New Brunswick]]. The tornado estimated in the lower F1 range (wind estimated around {{convert|120|km/h|abbr=on}}) caused structural damage to a few properties and uprooted/snapped a few trees along the corridor. The sighting of the actual funnel cloud / tornado was reported by a few members of the public. Ended at {{coord|47.7|N|64.85|W|type:landmark_region:CA-NB}} * August 20 – an F2 tornado hit the community of [[La Broquerie, Manitoba]], destroying a house. * August 24 – two tornadoes touch down near [[Unity, Saskatchewan|Unity]] and [[Yorkton, Saskatchewan]].
===2007=== * May 15 – [[Tornadoes of 2007#May 14–15|An F1 tornado]] struck the [[Mitchell, Ontario]] area around {{convert|60|km|abbr=on}} northeast of [[London, Ontario|London]], causing minor damage. The same storm system that caused this tornado also produced two other tornadoes (an F0 and an F1) in [[The Thumb]] area of [[Michigan]], northern [[Indiana]], and [[Ohio]] before crossing [[Lake Huron]] into Ontario. * June 22–23 – [[Tornadoes of 2007#June 21–24|A rare combination of weather systems converged]]. on a June weekend causing severe thunderstorms which spawned at least eight tornadoes across southeast [[Saskatchewan]] and [[southern Manitoba]]. The most significant, and the first confirmed F5 tornado in Canada which [[2007 Elie, Manitoba tornado|touched down]] near [[Elie, Manitoba|Elie]] destroying four homes, flipping one home-owner's [[Chrysler Fifth Avenue]] onto a neighbour's roof, and heavily damaging a flour mill. There were also sightings of three small tornadoes becoming one. One of the tornadoes in this outbreak also travelled {{convert|15|km|abbr=on}} south of Baldur and was rated an F3 on the Fujita scale.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2007/06/24/manitoba-tornadoes.html?ref=rss |title=CBC News – More tornadoes hit southern Manitoba |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070627134539/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2007/06/24/manitoba-tornadoes.html?ref=rss |archive-date=2007-06-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> A total of eight confirmed tornadoes over the two day span. * June 25 – a small tornado touches down near [[Standard, Alberta]], destroying a barn and electrocuting a horse. * June 26 – Environment Canada confirmed a tornado struck the [[Petitcodiac, New Brunswick]] in the [[Salisbury, New Brunswick|Salisbury]] area. The storm knocked down trees and hurled pieces of playground equipment and wheelbarrows long distances. In one incident, the twister picked up a trampoline from a front lawn and threw it {{convert|18|m|abbr=on}} into a pasture.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=53169766-1 |title=Environment Canada – Canada's Top Ten Weather Stories for 2007 |access-date=2012-06-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312065950/http://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=53169766-1 |archive-date=2013-03-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> * July 8 – a confirmed tornado touched down {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Mayerthorpe, Alberta]]. * July 8 – an F1 tornado was confirmed near [[Mildmay, Ontario]]. The tornado destroyed a large implementation shed and debris was reported {{convert|1.5|km|abbr=on}} away. Another tornado was sighted in the area but was unconfirmed. * July 23 – after a day of {{convert|40|C}} heat in the [[Edmonton]] area, a downward draft from the overhead [[jet stream]] formed a high-precipitation (HP) supercell, resulting in a tornado over [[Edmonton International Airport]] in [[Leduc County]] just before sundown. The tornado touched just south of the [[Alberta Highway 2|Highway 2]]/[[Alberta Highway 2A|2A]] junction, scattering rock, dirt, hay and small debris on {{convert|16|km|abbr=on}} of 2A, involving the towns of [[Kavanagh, Alberta|Kavanagh]] and [[Millet, Alberta|Millet]]. Despite its large appearance, no major damage or injuries were reported, although power was out for a few hours in the vicinity and lightning ignited a range fire west of the airport. * July 29 – an F0 tornado touched down near [[Gander Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador]]. The twister flipped a few snowmobile trailers over before dissipating. One of very few to strike the province.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/almanac/arc2008/alm08jun.htm |title=The Weather Doctor – Individual Tornado Events and Oddities |access-date=2008-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905075239/http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/almanac/arc2008/alm08jun.htm |archive-date=2008-09-05 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> * July 31 – a suspected tornado flattens fields and demolishes a farm yard near [[Cupar, Saskatchewan]] north of [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2007/08/02/cupar-storm.html CBC News – Cupar-area farm believed destroyed by tornado]</ref> * August 3 – an F2 tornado touched down in [[White Rapids, New Brunswick]]. ===2009===
*April 25 – five tornadoes were confirmed in [[Ontario]] after the passage of an intense cold front on the warmest day of spring. Four were rated as F0 in strength, and touched down in the towns of [[Killaloe, Hagarty and Richards|Round Lake Centre]], the west end of [[Ottawa]], [[Guelph]] and [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]]. Damage consisted of snapped trees, broken [[Hydroelectricity|hydro]] poles and roofs being peeled from buildings. Eighteen planes sustained damage at the [[Rockcliffe Flying Club]]. The fifth tornado was rated an F1, and hit the community of [[Breslau, Ontario|Breslau]], damaging a barn and silo and uprooting trees over a {{convert|1.4|km|abbr=on}} path. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=627B5C83-1 |title=Environment Canada – Canada's Top Ten Weather Stories for 2009 |access-date=2016-04-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418044353/https://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=627B5C83-1 |archive-date=2016-04-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *May 1 – an F0 tornado touched down near [[Normandin, Quebec]], snapping several utility poles.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=EA4C0989-1 |title=Environment Canada – Runner-up Weather Stories in 2009 |access-date=2016-04-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419032443/https://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=EA4C0989-1 |archive-date=2016-04-19 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *May 31 – an F0 tornado was confirmed approximately {{convert|18|km|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Calgary, Alberta]]. No damage was reported.<ref name="Year2009">{{Cite web |url=http://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/a720afb1-c271-4fbc-b55c-7d242e1701b6 |title=Government of Canada – Canadian National Tornado Database: Verified Events (1980–2009) – Public |access-date=2016-08-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704225653/http://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/a720afb1-c271-4fbc-b55c-7d242e1701b6 |archive-date=2016-07-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 1 – [[southern Manitoba]] saw its first major storm of the spring, which included an F0 tornado confirmed near [[Winnipeg]].<ref name=Year2009 /> *June 14 – an F0 tornado was reported and confirmed near Cloan, Saskatchewan, {{convert|40|km|abbr=on}} southwest of [[North Battleford]]. A second F0 tornado touched down near [[Municipal District of Provost No. 52#Communities and localities|Cairns]], ripping siding and roof tiles from structures.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090629052431/http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/Tornado%2Btakes%2Broof%2Bbarn/1735285/story.html Edmonton Journal – Tornado takes roof off barn]</ref> *June 25 – three tornadoes touched down in [[Southern Ontario]] in the afternoon hours. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/htdocs/data_fixe/page/en/p_suivi_climatologique/p_bilans_climatologiques_fermes/p_mensuel/2009_07.html |title=Climat-Quebec – July 2009 Climate Summary |access-date=2016-04-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404111433/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/htdocs/data_fixe/page/en/p_suivi_climatologique/p_bilans_climatologiques_fermes/p_mensuel/2009_07.html |archive-date=2017-04-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 29 – an F0 tornado touched down in the [[Les Rivières, Quebec City|Duberger]] district of [[Quebec City, Quebec]], uprooting trees and causing roof damage to homes.<ref>[http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p23&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en Climat-Quebec – 2009 Tornadoes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320173057/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p23&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en |date=2014-03-20 }}</ref> *July 30 – [[Buffalo Narrows, Saskatchewan]] saw an F0 tornado touch down. No damage was reported.<ref name=Year2009 /> *July 31 – an F0 tornado was confirmed near Telford, Manitoba.<ref name=Year2009 /> *August 1 – an F0 tornado touched down approximately {{convert|16|km|abbr=on}} north of [[Airdrie, Alberta]].<ref name=Year2009 /> * August 4 – an F2 tornado touched down between [[Déléage, Quebec|Déléage]] and [[Mont-Laurier, Quebec]], leaving a {{convert|40|km|abbr=on}} path of damage. Forty homes sustained damage, with twenty-eight rendered uninhabitable. Cars were tossed around, utility poles and power lines broken, and a number of trees were twisted and uprooted. It was the highest rated tornado in the province since 1994.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p20&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en |title=Climat-Quebec – Tornado in Mont-Laurier, August 4, 2009 |access-date=April 11, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404172137/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p20&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en |archive-date=April 4, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A cameraman for [[CFCF-DT|CFCF-TV]] and a helicopter pilot were killed a day later while gathering aerial footage of the damage.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/ctv-camera-operator-killed-in-helicopter-crash-1.422859 |title=CTV Montreal – CTV camera operator killed in helicopter crash |access-date=2016-04-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427145357/http://www.ctvnews.ca/ctv-camera-operator-killed-in-helicopter-crash-1.422859 |archive-date=2016-04-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> * August 20 – nineteen confirmed tornadoes touched down in Ontario, the largest single-day tornado outbreak in the province's history. Referred to as the [[Southern Ontario Tornado Outbreak of 2009]], it was one of the most destructive and costly tornado events ever in the province, and included one fatality. The four strongest tornadoes were given an F2 rating, with two of them hitting the densely populated city of [[Vaughan]]. Eleven of the tornadoes were given an F1 rating, and the last four were rated as F0. The lone fatality happened in the [[Durham, Ontario|Durham]] region, where an 11 year old was killed by flying debris. At one point, over 10 million people in Southern Ontario were placed under [[tornado watch]]es and/or [[tornado warning|warnings]]. It is also the largest tornado event in Canadian history.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/august-20-2009-ontarios-historic-tornado-outbreak/11359 |title=The Weather Network – August 20, 2009: Ontario's historic tornado outbreak |access-date=April 11, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424024739/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/august-20-2009-ontarios-historic-tornado-outbreak/11359 |archive-date=April 24, 2016 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *August 21 – two F0 tornadoes touched down in north central Quebec, one near the [[Baskatong Reservoir]] and the other near the town of [[La Tuque, Quebec|La Tuque]]. Minor damage was reported in wooded areas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/htdocs/data_fixe/page/en/p_suivi_climatologique/p_bilans_climatologiques_fermes/p_mensuel/2009_08.html |title=Climate-Quebec – August 2009 Climate Summary |access-date=2016-04-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404111400/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/htdocs/data_fixe/page/en/p_suivi_climatologique/p_bilans_climatologiques_fermes/p_mensuel/2009_08.html |archive-date=2017-04-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *August 22 – a weak F0 tornado touched down in the city of [[Markham, Ontario]], travelling for about {{convert|3|km|abbr=on}} and causing minor damage.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://highwaysandhailstones.com/tornado-map/august-22-2009-markham/ |title=Highways and Hailstones – Cone tornado touches down, travels 3km through city but with only minor damage |access-date=2016-04-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329161202/http://highwaysandhailstones.com/tornado-map/august-22-2009-markham/ |archive-date=2016-03-29 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *September 28 – an F1 tornado was confirmed near [[Bowmanville, Ontario]], damaging barns and uprooting trees. It travelled for approximately {{convert|7|km|abbr=on}} to [[Orono, Ontario|Orono]] before dissipating.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/bowmanville-hit-by-tornado-says-environment-canada-1.438828 |title=CTV Toronto – Bowmanville hit by tornado, says Environment Canada |access-date=2016-04-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427114408/http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/bowmanville-hit-by-tornado-says-environment-canada-1.438828 |archive-date=2016-04-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>

== 2010s ==
===2010=== * June 6 – an F1 tornado touched down in [[Leamington, Ontario]] over the early morning hours before dissipating near [[Point Pelee National Park]]. Damage was estimated to be in the "millions", as the twister uprooted trees and damaged houses and cars, leaving a {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} path. Luckily, considering the time the tornado hit, there were no reports of injuries or deaths.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://windsorstar.com/news/topic.html?t=Keyword&q=Leamington+tornado |title=The Windsor Star – Leamington Tornado coverage |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402015940/http://www.windsorstar.com/news/topic.html?t=Keyword&q=Leamington+tornado |archive-date=2012-04-02 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> * June 6 – an F1 tornado was confirmed in [[Eastern Ontario]], near the villages of [[North Glengarry, Ontario|Dalkeith]] and [[East Hawkesbury|Ste-Anne-de-Prescott]] close to the Quebec border. * June 21 – two weak tornadoes touch down near [[Limerick, Saskatchewan|Limerick]] and [[Avonlea, Saskatchewan]]. * June 22 – a possible tornado destroyed a garage and ripped a roof off a house in [[Rural Municipality of Woodlands|Woodlands, Manitoba]] about {{convert|60|km|abbr=on}} north of [[Winnipeg]]. * June 23 – two confirmed tornadoes touched down near the town of [[Midland, Ontario]]. The first tornado was rated an F2 and it touched down at approximately 6:30 pm EDT (UTC−04:00) near the [[Tiny, Ontario|Rowntree Beach]] area and ended near [[Tay, Ontario|Waubaushene]], a length of {{convert|25|km|abbr=on}}. A second tornado rated an F1 spawned from the same [[thunderstorm]], touched down around 7 pm EDT (UTC−04:00), just west of [[Ramara|Washago]]. Its path lasted {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}}. [[Tornado warning]]s did go off 12 minutes before the first tornado struck, leaving some residents unprepared. In addition a ''[[Red Alert (Ontario)|Red Alert]]'' was even issued by the Emergency Management of Ontario in a huge swath of [[Central Ontario]]. Both twisters left 15 people injured, 8 seriously. There were no fatalities. That same evening after 9 pm EDT (UTC−04:00, storms tracked through the [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]]-[[Essex County, Ontario|Essex County]] area, where a [[microburst]] caused damage near [[Colchester, Ontario|Colchester]] destroying a party tent and part of a garage, with funnel clouds and a possible tornado reported in the rural areas of the town of [[Essex, Ontario|Essex]], these tornadoes came on the same day just hours after [[2010 Central Canada earthquake|Central Canada was rocked by an earthquake]]. * June 23 – a confirmed tornado touched down near [[Rural Municipality of Rosser|Rosser, Manitoba]], but with little damage. Funnel clouds were also spotted near [[Marquette, Manitoba|Marquette]] and [[Elie, Manitoba|Elie]] coming a day before the third anniversary of the F5 Elie tornado. * June 24 – a possible tornado touched down near [[Wilkie, Saskatchewan]]. * June 25 – an unconfirmed tornado touched down near [[Oxbow, Saskatchewan]], damaging a farm.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2010/06/28/sk-twister-farmyard-1006.html CBC Regina – Twister damages farm]</ref> * June 27 – an early-afternoon repeat of June 23, severe thunderstorms form in [[Southeast Michigan]] and track towards [[Windsor, Ontario]], spawning a minor tornado from [[Essex, Ontario|Essex]] to roughly Staples, with a second forming near [[Kingsville, Ontario|Cottam]], in central [[Essex County, Ontario|Essex County]]. * June 28 – two F0 tornadoes touched down in the [[Montreal]] region, one in [[Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue, Quebec]], on Montreal's [[West Island]], and one in [[Mascouche]], east of the city. Many funnel clouds were also spotted in the area(s). * June 29 – a confirmed tornado touched down near [[Whitecourt, Alberta]], northwest of [[Edmonton]]. No damage was reported. * July 2 – an F3 tornado tore through the Kawacatoose Reserve near [[Raymore, Saskatchewan]]. Some homes on the reserve were demolished, with several others sustaining damage. It also levelled farmhouses and farms west of the town. It left a {{convert|500|m|abbr=on}} wide path that was {{convert|45|km|abbr=on}} long. No lives were lost, but some people received broken bones, cuts and bruises. It was stated that the tornado could have possibly been on the ground for an hour.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2010/07/05/sk-tornado-update-1007.html CBC Regina – Sask. tornado confirmed as F3]</ref> *July 13 – a confirmed tornado touched down {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} east of [[Carman, Manitoba]]. No rating was given for the twister, as no damage was reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://winnipeg.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100714/wpg_weather_warnings_100714/20100714/?hub=WinnipegHome |title=CTV Winnipeg – Province looks at improving weather warning system |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323232959/http://winnipeg.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100714/wpg_weather_warnings_100714/20100714/?hub=WinnipegHome |archive-date=2012-03-23 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 17 – an F0 tornado hit the community of [[Saint-Lazare, Quebec]], near [[Montreal]]. The tornado damaged some homes, and toppled trees. Two people were also struck by lightning associated with the storm.<ref>[http://montreal.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100717/mtl_lightening_100717/20100717/?hub=MontrealHome CTV Montreal – Lightning strikes couple, tornado touches down in St. Lazare]</ref> *July 22 – an unconfirmed tornado touched down just north of [[Regina, Saskatchewan]]. No damage was reported. *July 23 – an F0 tornado touched down in [[Amherstburg, Ontario]] around 7 pm EDT (UTC−04:00). The path was around {{convert|1|km|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}} wide. The small tornado travelled directly north for a short distance, damaging trees and a roof on small outbuilding, before turning east and dissipating a short time later. There were no injuries reported. The same system also caused a [[downburst]] in [[Kingsville, Ontario|Kingsville]]. Another tornado may have touched down near Ruthven, although nothing has been confirmed. *July 25 – two confirmed tornadoes were spotted near the town of [[Lanigan, Saskatchewan]], southeast of [[Saskatoon]]. Two more tornadoes touched down near the town of [[Humboldt, Saskatchewan|Humboldt]]. Most damage came from the golf-ball-sized hail associated with the storms, which destroyed several crops in the area. *July 26 – a confirmed tornado touched down near [[Oakbank, Manitoba]], {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} east of Winnipeg. *July 30 – around 3:20 pm MDT (UTC−06:00), a confirmed tornado touched down northwest of [[Sundre, Alberta]], {{convert|120|km|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Calgary]]. There were reports of heavy rain and large hail, but no damage. Another possible tornado touched down {{convert|50|km|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Water Valley, Alberta|Water Valley]], but was not confirmed. *August 22 – Alberta, a tornado was reported southwest of [[Grande Prairie]].

===2011=== * April 27 – [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Environment Canada]] confirmed an F0 tornado touched down near the town of [[Fergus, Ontario]], as a part of the [[2011 Super Outbreak]]. Multiple trees were blown over, siding was torn from buildings and a large air conditioning unit was thrown from the roof of a retail store.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110509/weather-wind-april-2011-environment-canada-110509/20110509/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto – First Tornado of 2011 |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406211235/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110509/weather-wind-april-2011-environment-canada-110509/20110509/?hub=TorontoNewHome |archive-date=2012-04-06 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *May 28 – a tornado touched down briefly about {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]] at about 5:30 pm [[Central Time Zone|CDT]] ([[UTC−05:00]]) in [[St. Adolphe, Manitoba|St. Adolphe]]. The twister was likely an F0, but was not confirmed. It touched down in a field, lifted some debris and then dissipated. *June 2 – a weak F0 tornado was spotted northwest of [[Shaunavon, Saskatchewan]] as severe thunderstorms hit the area. The [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) reported damage to [[granary|granaries]] in the area, and several power lines were toppled.<ref>[http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=weak_tornado_reported_in_sas_020611?ref=ccbox_weather_topstories The Weather Network – Weak Tornado reported in Saskatchewan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402140115/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3Dweak_tornado_reported_in_sas_020611?ref=ccbox_weather_topstories |date=2012-04-02 }}</ref> *June 23 – an F0 tornado briefly touched down near the [[Ottawa River]] and moved towards [[Aylmer, Quebec]]. No damage was reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110624/OTT_WATER_110624/20110624/?hub=OttawaHome |title=CTV Ottawa – Storms hammer region |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327085503/http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110624/OTT_WATER_110624/20110624/?hub=OttawaHome |archive-date=2012-03-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 23 – an unconfirmed tornado was sighted near [[Fox Valley, Saskatchewan]], about {{convert|325|km|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Saskatoon]]. Damage was reported to a hardware store and some city roads. Power lines were also knocked down.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.maplecreeknews.com/news/local-news/1081-tornado-strikes-fox-valley.html |title=Maple Creek News – Tornado strikes Fox Valley |access-date=2014-07-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715000107/http://www.maplecreeknews.com/news/local-news/1081-tornado-strikes-fox-valley.html |archive-date=2014-07-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 7 – multiple tornadoes touched down in [[Central Alberta]] from very strong thunderstorms that swept across the province. One touched down near the town of [[Bergen, Alberta|Bergen]], and the others near the towns of [[Olds, Alberta|Olds]] and [[Bowden, Alberta|Bowden]]. One of the hardest hit areas was near [[Innisfail, Alberta|Innisfail]], where three farms were damaged. A {{convert|180,000|sqft|abbr=on}} riding area{{clarify|reason=Is this used as in an electoral district or a place where horses are ridden?|date=August 2016}} was also destroyed. There were also reports of hail the size of softballs causing damage to cars and houses.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://calgary.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110708/edm_storms_110708/20110708/?hub=CalgaryHome |title=CTV Calgary – Damage left behind as twister touched down near Innisfail |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325124729/http://calgary.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110708/edm_storms_110708/20110708/?hub=CalgaryHome |archive-date=2012-03-25 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 13 – a weak F0 tornado touched down in southwestern [[Calgary, Alberta]]. It was originally classified a funnel cloud by Environment Canada, but amateur video of the event showed it was a tornado.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/tornado-hit-southwest-calgary-1.999659 |title=CBC News Calgary – Tornado hit southwest Calgary |access-date=2014-07-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724184203/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/tornado-hit-southwest-calgary-1.999659 |archive-date=2015-07-24 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 18 – a tornado was reported about {{convert|15|km|abbr=on}} north of [[Big River, Saskatchewan]], with multiple funnel clouds also reported around the same time. The same storm system later pelted the resort of [[Prince Albert National Park|Waskesiu]] with baseball-sized hail causing property damage around the townsite with damage to windows, siding and roofs.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://northernprideml.com/2011/07/26/storm-aftermath-in-photos/ |title=Northern Pride – Storm aftermath in photos |access-date=2014-07-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714195600/http://northernprideml.com/2011/07/26/storm-aftermath-in-photos/ |archive-date=2014-07-14 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 20 – an F1 tornado touched down between [[Saguenay, Quebec|Saguenay]] and [[Quebec City, Quebec]]. Winds were strong enough to pick up a moving car off the highway.<ref>[http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=tallying_canadas_confirmed__250711 The Weather Network – Tallying Canada's confirmed tornadoes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402140638/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3Dtallying_canadas_confirmed__250711 |date=2012-04-02 }}</ref> *July 23 – an F2 tornado touched down southeast of [[Plympton–Wyoming|Wyoming, Ontario]], and carved a path {{convert|500|m|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|11|km|abbr=on}} long. It dissipated just south of [[Warwick, Ontario|Watford]], after blowing over eight steel transmission towers and also knocking down several hydro poles. Other damage reports included several trees snapped off and buildings moved from their foundations. One barn was completely destroyed.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/story/2011/07/26/wdr-tornado-confirmed-in-lambton-county.html |title=CBC Windsor – Tornado confirmed in Lambton County |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110004731/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/story/2011/07/26/wdr-tornado-confirmed-in-lambton-county.html |archive-date=2012-11-10 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *August 6 – an F1 tornado touched down in the village of [[Passes-Dangereuses, Quebec|Sainte-Élisabeth-de-Proulx, Quebec]], roughly {{convert|30|km|abbr=on}} north of [[Lac Saint-Jean]]. Multiple cottages were damaged, and trees uprooted. Environment Canada is also looking into another possible tornado in the [[Saint-Ludger-de-Milot]] area.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2011/08/08/quebec-tornado.html |title=CBC News – Heavy tornado damage in Lac Saint-Jean area |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809010258/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2011/08/08/quebec-tornado.html |archive-date=2011-08-09 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *August 8 – a weak F0 tornado occurred in the town of [[Blandford-Blenheim|Plattsville, Ontario]], about {{convert|18|km|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]]. There was no damage reported. *August 16 – four F1 tornadoes touched down in the heavily wooded areas of [[Northwestern Ontario]]. The first occurred near [[Dryden, Ontario|Dryden]], leaving a {{convert|24|km|abbr=on}} trail. The second touched down about {{convert|30|km|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Sioux Lookout]], leaving a {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}} path. The third was confirmed in the [[Ear Falls]]-Wenesaga Lake area, about {{convert|100|km|abbr=on}} north of Dryden. It left a very small path of {{convert|1|km|abbr=on}}. The fourth F1 also touched down in Ear Falls, near Gerry Lake, leaving a {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} path. All four tornadoes were given the F1 rating because of the amount of tree damage, and lack of structural damage. *August 21 – an F3 [[2011 Goderich, Ontario tornado|tornado hit Goderich, Ontario]] in the late afternoon hours. A [[supercell thunderstorm]] formed and intensified over [[Lake Huron]], spawning a [[waterspout]] which came ashore and passed directly through the heart of [[Goderich, Ontario|Goderich]]. At its widest over downtown, the tornado was estimated to be {{convert|1.5|km|abbr=on}} across, and its path was an estimated {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} long. It caused devastating damage to the town's port and historic downtown centre, as well as to several blocks of residential homes. Approximately forty people were injured and one person was killed. It was Ontario's strongest tornado since 1996. *August 21 – a very weak F1 tornado occurred in the west end of [[Gananoque, Ontario]], twisting trees and demolishing a shed. The track was close to {{convert|1.5|km|abbr=on}} before it dissipated. *August 24 – two confirmed F1 tornadoes hit [[Southwestern Ontario]], after a line of severe storms swept through the province. The first touched down in the town of Little Corners, near [[Cambridge, Ontario|Cambridge]] and left a {{convert|15|km|abbr=on}} path of toppled trees. The second touched down {{convert|6|km|abbr=on}} west of [[North Middlesex, Ontario|Nairn]] and left a {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} trail before it dissipated. A third F0 tornado also touched down in the southwestern part of [[Grey County]], near [[Neustadt, Ontario|Neustadt]]. The track was around {{convert|3|km|abbr=on}} long and left damage mostly to trees.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110831/110831_tornado/20110831/?hub=CP24Home |title=CP24 – Environment Canada confirms third tornado in Ontario |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319150352/http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110831/110831_tornado/20110831/?hub=CP24Home |archive-date=2012-03-19 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *September 3 – Environment Canada confirmed that an F0 tornado occurred just west of the town of [[Grimsby, Ontario]]. A large [[gazebo]] was destroyed and branches were knocked from trees. The path of damage was close to {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} long, and the maximum width was around {{convert|300|m|abbr=on}}. No injuries were reported. *September 4 – an F0 tornado hit the western part of [[Trois-Rivières, Quebec]] in the early evening hours. Damage reports indicated that trees were uprooted, roofs torn off and power was knocked out. The tornado did not last long and there were no reported injuries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2011/09/05/tornado-trois-rivieres.html |title=CBC.ca – Tornado touchdown confirmed in Trois-Rivières |access-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906134559/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2011/09/05/tornado-trois-rivieres.html |archive-date=2011-09-06 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *September 18 – an unconfirmed tornado was spotted east of [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]]. No damage was reported, and the twister did not last very long.

===2012=== *May 22 – a late-afternoon F0 tornado touched down in a field east of [[Orono, Ontario]]. It dissipated quickly, and no injuries or damage was reported.<ref>[http://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3568151 The Peterborough Examiner – Orono funnel cloud was likely an F0 Tornado]</ref> *May 25 – two low-level tornadoes were confirmed in rural areas northwest of [[Montreal, Quebec]]. An F0 touched down near the town of [[Brownsburg-Chatham, Quebec|Brownsburg-Chatham]] around 8 pm EDT (UTC−03:00), followed by an F1 that swept through the [[Saint-Benoît, Quebec|Saint-Benoît]] sector of [[Mirabel, Quebec|Mirabel]]. Both tornadoes caused extensive damage estimated to be in the millions. No one was injured.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120526/tornado-confirmed-near-montreal-120526/ |title=CTVNews.ca – Tornadoes cause millions in damage in Quebec |access-date=2012-05-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527034053/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120526/tornado-confirmed-near-montreal-120526/ |archive-date=2012-05-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *May 29 – a confirmed F0 tornado touched down east of [[Ottawa]], in the small community of [[Bourget, Ontario]]. The tornado was short lived and caused minor roof damage and uprooted trees.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2012/05/30/ott-tornado-forms-bourget.html |title=CBC News – Tornado Confirmed east of Ottawa |access-date=2012-05-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531044951/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2012/05/30/ott-tornado-forms-bourget.html |archive-date=2012-05-31 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 5 – at least one confirmed tornado touched down {{convert|9|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Taber, Alberta]], knocking out power in parts of the town. At least three others were reported near [[Turin, Alberta|Turin]], [[Brooks, Alberta|Brooks]], and [[Bow Island]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DStormy_system_invades_western_Canada_04_06_2012 |title=The Weather Network – Tornadoes touch down in southern Alberta |access-date=2012-06-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607212434/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DStormy_system_invades_western_Canada_04_06_2012 |archive-date=2012-06-07 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 8 – an F1 tornado touched down in [[Huntingdon, Quebec]], severely damaging a gas station and uprooting trees.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DStormy_system_invades_western_Canada_04_06_2012 |title=The Weather Network – F1 tornado touchdown in Huntingdon, Quebec |access-date=2012-06-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607212434/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DStormy_system_invades_western_Canada_04_06_2012 |archive-date=2012-06-07 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 9 – an unconfirmed tornado touched down north of [[Stettler, Alberta]]. [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Environment Canada]] referred to it as a "landspout tornado", which is essentially a funnel cloud that touches the ground in a weak thunderstorm system. A farm sustained minor damage to some grain bins, and tree limbs were snapped.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/story/2012/06/09/calgary-landspout-tornado-stettler.html |title=CBC News Calgary – Landspout tornado reported near Stettler, Alta. |access-date=2012-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616081852/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/story/2012/06/09/calgary-landspout-tornado-stettler.html |archive-date=2012-06-16 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 15 – eight tornadoes were confirmed near the communities of Plover Lake, [[Biggar, Saskatchewan|Biggar]] and [[Wilkie, Saskatchewan]]. There were several reports of funnel clouds throughout the evening. No damage was reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DTornadoes_and_funnel_clouds_hit_west-central_Sasketchwan_15_06_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_category1 |title=The Weather Network – Eight confirmed tornadoes hit west-central Saskatchewan |access-date=2012-06-19 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130204094713/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=Tornadoes_and_funnel_clouds_hit_west-central_Sasketchwan_15_06_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_category1 |archive-date=2013-02-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 18 – an F1 tornado touched down near [[Sioux Lookout, Ontario]], knocking down several trees.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DEC_confirms_tornado_passed_near_Sioux_lookout_June_18_29_06_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_topstories |title=The Weather Network – EC confirms tornado passed near Sioux Lookout on June 18 |access-date=2012-06-30 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130204124845/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=EC_confirms_tornado_passed_near_Sioux_lookout_June_18_29_06_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_topstories |archive-date=2013-02-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *June 26 – one tornado was confirmed near the town of [[Caron, Saskatchewan]] and another was reported near [[Hodgeville, Saskatchewan|Hodgeville]]. Environment Canada received 500 reports of funnel clouds over a 36-hour period. Damage was limited to farmers fields and grain silos and no injuries were reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.globaltvedmonton.com/environment+canada+gets+500+reports+of+tornadoes+in+36+hours+in+saskatchewan/6442669960/story.html |title=Global News Edmonton – EC gets 500 reports of tornadoes in 36 hours |access-date=2016-09-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820082109/http://www.globaltvedmonton.com/environment+canada+gets+500+reports+of+tornadoes+in+36+hours+in+saskatchewan/6442669960/story.html |archive-date=2012-08-20 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 3 – at least three tornadoes were confirmed in Saskatchewan. One touched down near the town of [[Davidson, Saskatchewan|Davidson]], and did heavy damage to a farm. The other two touched down southwest of [[Wynyard, Saskatchewan|Wynyard]] and southwest of [[Watrous, Saskatchewan|Watrous]]. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/story/2012/07/03/sk-tornado-warning.html |title=CBC News – Tornadoes touch down in Saskatchewan |access-date=2012-07-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704183608/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/story/2012/07/03/sk-tornado-warning.html |archive-date=2012-07-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 3 – an F1 tornado touched down {{convert|13|km|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Olds, Alberta]], taking the roof off a house. Damage was also reported to a barn and hay shed, and multiple trees were uprooted. No injuries were reported.<ref>[https://vancouversun.com/news/alberta/Tornado+touches+down+near+Olds+Alberta/6881696/story.html The Vancouver Sun – Tornado touches down near Olds, Alberta]</ref><ref>[https://calgaryherald.com/news/alberta/Experts+getting+more+severe+storms+southern+Alberta+harder/6885077/story.html The Calgary Herald – Storms hitting southern Alberta harder than usual, experts say]</ref> *July 17 – two tornadoes were confirmed in [[Eastern Ontario]], hitting the small communities of [[Athens, Ontario|Athens]] and [[South Glengarry, Ontario|Summerstown]]. The Athens tornado was rated an F1, with winds speeds estimated at {{convert|140|km/h|abbr=on}} at touchdown. It left a track of damage {{convert|300|m|abbr=on}} wide and about {{convert|3|km|abbr=on}} long. Several trees were snapped off or uprooted, damaging houses and cars. A farm just west of town had several hay wagons flipped over, and it tore the woodshed and chimney off a house. The Summerstown twister was rated as a likely F0, and its path was {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} wide and about {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} long. Several trees were knocked down, and crops sustained some damage.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2012/07/18/ottawa-eastern-ontario-communities-cleaningup.html |title=CBC News Ottawa – 2 tornadoes touched down amid eastern Ontario storms |access-date=2012-07-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719040701/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2012/07/18/ottawa-eastern-ontario-communities-cleaningup.html |archive-date=2012-07-19 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 18 – three confirmed tornadoes touched down in central parts of [[Saskatchewan]]. The twisters were reported east of [[Rose Valley, Saskatchewan|Rose Valley]], and at least two more were spotted north and east of [[Wadena, Saskatchewan|Wadena]]. No damage was reported.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.globalsaskatoon.com/at+least+three+confirmed+tornadoes+in+saskatchewan/6442681811/story.html |title=Global Saskatoon – At least 3 confirmed tornadoes in Saskatchewan |access-date=2016-09-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721182644/http://www.globalsaskatoon.com/at+least+three+confirmed+tornadoes+in+saskatchewan/6442681811/story.html |archive-date=2012-07-21 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 21 – two confirmed tornadoes touched down in near [[Smeaton, Saskatchewan]], where a house was destroyed, and a 72-year-old man inside escaped unharmed. It also knocked trees down and grain bins over. A second reported tornado touched down near [[Emma Lake (Saskatchewan)|Emma Lake]]. There were no reports of damage. *July 22 – an F0 tornado touched down near the town of [[Zorra|Embro, Ontario]]. An Environment Canada employee witnessed the weak tornado in a field; It left no damage.<ref>[http://www.weatheroffice.gc.ca/warnings/SWS_bulletins_e.html?prov=on Environment Canada – F0 Tornado in Embro] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030230915/http://www.weatheroffice.gc.ca/warnings/SWS_bulletins_e.html?prov=on |date=2012-10-30 }}</ref> *July 24 – [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Environment Canada]] confirmed that five tornadoes touched down in [[Saskatchewan]]. Minor damage was reported to farm buildings. There was no official word on the strengths of the twisters.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DFive_tornadoes_touched_down_briefly_in_rural_Saskatchewan_Tuesday_25_07_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_topstories |title=The Weather Network – 5 tornadoes touch down in Saskatchewan |access-date=2012-07-26 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130204044703/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=Five_tornadoes_touched_down_briefly_in_rural_Saskatchewan_Tuesday_25_07_2012?ref=ccbox_homepage_topstories |archive-date=2013-02-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *July 28 – a brief tornado touched down about {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Cremona, Alberta]]. Damage was reported to a nearby farm.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://prairiestormtranquillity.wordpress.com/2012/07/29/july-282012-dogpound-alberta-supercell-and-tornado/ |title=Prairie Storm Tranquillity – Dogpound, Alberta Supercell and Tornado |access-date=2012-07-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801212320/http://prairiestormtranquillity.wordpress.com/2012/07/29/july-282012-dogpound-alberta-supercell-and-tornado/ |archive-date=2012-08-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *August 2 – an unconfirmed tornado touched down near [[Lake Diefenbaker]], around the town of [[Elbow, Saskatchewan]]. No damage or injuries were reported. *August 11 – an F0 tornado was confirmed near [[Midland, Ontario]]. *August 30 – an F0 tornado touched down near [[Chibougamau, Quebec]]. Damage was reported at a campground where several trees were uprooted. *September 8 – an early evening F0 tornado touched down in [[Drummondville, Quebec]]. A roof was blown off a 4-storey building and thrown across the street while other buildings and vehicles sustained minor damage.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/09/09/tornado-drummondville.html |title=CBC News Montreal – Tornado touches down in Drummondville |access-date=2012-09-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910080347/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/09/09/tornado-drummondville.html |archive-date=2012-09-10 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *September 8 – [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Environment Canada]] confirmed that an F2 tornado touched down near the town of [[Loyalist, Ontario|Odesssa, Ontario]]. Two properties received minor damage to lawn furniture and trees.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DOntario_s_9th_tornado_of_the_year_confirmed_24_09_2012?ref=ccbox_archive_topstories |title=The Weather Network – Ontario's 9th tornado of the year confirmed |access-date=2012-09-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127045026/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DOntario_s_9th_tornado_of_the_year_confirmed_24_09_2012?ref=ccbox_archive_topstories |archive-date=2012-11-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> *October 31 – a weak F0 tornado touched down near the town of [[Mont-Laurier, Quebec]], destroying a barn and blowing road signs over.
